title: Clarus the DogCow
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Clarus the DogCow is a geek mascot related to early Macintosh developers (1984-2000).
To learn more about Clarus : http://clarus.chez-alice.fr The OpenScad source file can compute 6 different models (see source file). STL are computed models, ready to be print. At that time a small hole has been made behind the figure to snap a support, but the support is not modeled.
  • Model #0 : Original design from Cairo Font (Susan Kare, 1983)
  • Model #1 : The most famous, redesign for "Page Set Up" dialog for Apple Printer from 1987 to 2000
  • Model #2 : a smaller variation from #1
  • Model #3 : smaller design to fit 32x32 pixels icons
  • Model #4 : the smallest variation : DogCattle
  • Model #5 : redesign by Susan Kare in 1999 with a "more bovine head"
    • Moof!
The openscad source define the different figurine as bitmap tab (0: nothing, 1: level 1 and 2: level 2...) so it can be adjust to render any bitmap source into a simple 3D model.

title: Bike Helmet Mount for GoPro Gimbal (Parameterized)

description.text:
My roommate recently got a handheld steady-cam type gimbal for his GoPro camera, and wanted to mount it on his bike helmet.  So I whipped this up, stuck it to his helmet with servo tape, added a 3mm x 20mm screw and nut, and away he rode.  
[update] Now Customizable

If you need to tweak the sizes for this design:
  • Unpack the .zip file.
  • Edit the .scad file to tweak the parameters.
  • Open the .scad file with OpenSCAD.
  • Select Render from the Design menu.
  • Select "Export as STL..." from the File->Export menu.
  • Save the STL file.
  • Slice the STL file.
  • Print.

title: Gutter cleaner Attrachment for Toro 24 volt leaf blower

description.text:
Add a short length of 1 1/2 inch schedule 40 PVC or ABS pipe and two  right elbow, and you have the perfect tool to help you to blow the spring time maple whirling seeds or fall time leaves out of your gutter. 
Update, 11-2-2016 -  I added a second version of the blower extension blower extenstion design 3 longer and tighter.123dx. and     for those who want a firmer attachment to both the pvc pipe and the blower end.

The fitting (blower extension) with the larger size should fit snugly over the end of the Toro model 51702T 24Volt leaf blowers.  May also fit others with similar dimensions (outside of tip 26 mm X 65 mm) The blower out is used for the exit port if you want a similar nozzle to the original blower design.   
You will need to have 2 90 deg elbows, and cut a few lengths of PVC schedule 40 pipe as shown in the photo.  My fittings were pretty snug so i only used the cement to connect the nozzles (so they would not blow off.)

comments.text: Oh, so brilliant.  Not my model, but when gutter cleaning time comes, I'll measure up and make one for mine!

remixed_from.author: milehighdesign
remixed_from.title: B3 Pico Hot End in A Divinci 1.0

title: Mod XYZ Da Vinci to use Pico hot end

description.text:
After flashing Repetier firmware I wanted to mod My Da Vinci to allow for printing with other filament types than ABS. These are the parts I printed to mount a B3 Pico Hot end. So far I am able to print ABS, PLA, NinjaFlex, and PTEG. This is a remix from a E3d Mod the parts were a bit too large to fit the groove mount on the pico, I Redrew that in the STLs. The pico end can be purchased here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vX9r4Ncr4dU Get the groove mount version. Update 26MAY2015:
I have included some pics of samples that I have done in ABS, PLA, Laywood, and Bridge Nylon. THese all worked fairly easily in the temp ranges they recommended. So far Fila-flex has been temperamental, and ABS with Carbon fiber needed a larger diameter opening on the hot end nozzle. It is on the way.

FOR THE PARTS:
pretty straight forward, I would familiarize yourself with the breakdown of the Da Vinci by watching this series of videos. Do not be confused by all of the parts for the E3d end the Pico is already assembled and ready to go. Also, I bought new screws to replace because the thickness of the mod they are M3 X10, M3X12, and M3x35. Also you will need some M3 nuts (4 for the fan) So disassemble, and reassemble as he shows in the video, I found the whole thing was a bit wobbly so I also printed the gasket part in Filaflex after the first step disassembled it a 2nd time and put in the gasket. FOR THE PCB:
Remove the Spring clip to mount the PCB clip. (I flipped the PCB upside down by mistake in the pictures) Aligned the filament sensor with the feed tube, and zip strip it into place (i do not want to drill holes in the PCB. FOR THE FAN: Take the existing 5V fan and install it to draw air out across the Pico where it is clipped on. re-attach to the PCB board and the fan will still be under the firmware control. FOR FLEX:
To constrain the Flex filament I took a short bit of the PTFE tube from the filament feed and slipped into the cold side of the Pico it just fits, I then fed it under the extruder and stretched it a bit to help guide the filament into the extruder. PHOTOS:
In the pictures, for the most part I printed in white to be easier to see, however in a few of the earlier shots the PCB clip was the original shape and in blue. Also, please do not comment on the dangly wires, I pulled the plastic wraps and enclosed them all after these photos. I am very pleased with the results. Please be sure to ask if you have any questions.

comments.text: re 285 degree tightening, the ally will expand at a different rate to the brass and the nozzle will become loose, i use the same principle to fit aluminium parts over steel by putting the steel in a freezer and the ally in an oven, then when they are the same temp if the fit was tight enough it wont ever move without considerable force.

description.text: Simple robot that fits nicely to the Robodyssey RAMB II Basic and RAMB III Teensy motherboards. Update: I finally got together a nice affordable kit...if you don't have servos, screws and such already. Check it out here: http://www.pattonrobotics.com

Everything assembles with 4-40 self tapping screws. The wheels have a small hole that can fit a servo screw. I tend to tap the servos 4-40 and thus you will need to widen the wheel hole.
1) Screw the top to the bottom first
2) Screw the servos into the bottom
3) Attach the wheels
4) Place an O ring around the wheels
5) Snap a marble into the bottom cylinder.
6) Attach a Sharp sensor to the support and screw into the top frame
7) Place in a 6pk of AA batteries and attach the RAMB with screws.
For video instructions see my video here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117668

description.text:
I haven't noticed a spool holder on here specifically for the Dibond version of the Mendel 90, so I made one. It's based strongly on fest's version for the acrylic panel machine.  
I haven't tried it with more than one spool but I can't imagine it would be a problem.  
As always, I'd love to see yours if you print them.  
Ross

I used ABS with 25% infill for mine and they seem fine so far.   
The metal bar in the picture is a 450mm length of 10mm diameter aluminium extrusion but you can use any 10mm diameter rod. The hole in the bracket is actually 11mm in the stl but it comes out a bit tight so a 10mm rod fits well.  
It doesn't need screwing to the machine, just a push fit. You will need to print with support to generate the part which sits over the Mendel90 frame.

description.text:
I wanted to replace the original RAM MOUNT for my Garmin ZUMO 220. This is the final version of my own holder for 22mm handlebar on my wife's Yamaha XJ6. Works fine, no vibrations, no problems :)
It will work on any other/similar motorbike with 22mm handlebar and min. 80mm distance between holders.

Make 1 top piece + 2 bottom pieces, You'll also need the original plastic bracket for Zumo 220 (the version for motorbikes with 3 holes for RAM MOUNT), 3 original screws/washers/nuts + 4 new screws M5x50 with conical heads and 4 nuts and washers.

title: Chinese 3D Printer - 3 Position Build Plate Replacement

description.text:
I designed this as a replacement to my Chinese Replicator Dual clone's crappy build plate. I added tabs to allow me to use Binder Clips to hold glass 240 mm x 160 mm in diameter without sacrificing real estate. The files are provided for you to print out a full sized model and check for fit on your printer. If it works and you are interested in one of these please contact me. It is overall 230 mm x 160 mm x 6mm thick and made fro the toughest aluminum alloy available. UPDATE 9/13/2015
If you want one of these for your Chinese 3D printer and I do not have a part that fits it, if you will give me the dimensions of your plate and circuit board with placement of the holes and the rear connector I will give you $25 off your purchase of the first plate. NOTE: They will be orange and either say BOXBOT or show our logo which is laser etched into the plate to no measurable depth. I am currently using both borosillicate glass and picture frame glass and the picture frame glass is holding up nicely when printing ABS with the plate heated to 110c. I am also using Suave Hair Spray and I find it works better than cheaper hair sprays. These tabbed build plates will be offered for sale on boxbot.net for $75 plus shipping. Includes the build plate and binder clips.

I designed this as a replacement to my Chinese Replicator Dual clone's crappy build plate. I added tabs to allow me to use Binder Clips to hold glass 240 mm x 160 mm in diameter without sacrificing real estate.  
The files are provided for you to print out a full sized model and check for fit on your printer. If it works and you are interested in one of these please contact me. It is overall 230 mm x 160 mm x 5mm thick and made fro the toughest aluminum alloy available.   
You can print the LEFT and RIGHT parts and glue them together or print the PDF on card stock and cut out the holes.

Well that is if you used the paper clips. Here are 2 ideas I am going to play with using your design as a basis.
1) Make the plate deeper in Y-Axis about 1" both sides, then on the tabs you could add spring load clips. Just have to dill some holes in the new plate tabs and design/make some L=clips with a bolt, nut, washer and coil spring (or just a wing nut and tighten as needed).
2) Build a swing up wire C-clips that hinges on the bottom the tabs on the tab angles edges. Similar to the UP 2 Plus 3d Printer.

remixed_from.author: luke12345
remixed_from.title: FFFiddle Remixes for Pickup's Internal Plug & Cheaper Guitar Tuners

description.text:
Warning don't print the neck yet ...it doesnt print well due to bad hoverhangs This is my version of the 20x20 cut of the f-f-fiddle !
It uses the neck from the original puzzle and the modified bout from strocknar for additional tuners (which is the modified version from luke12345).
My own modifications are two other holes for pickups (in the openscad) and of course the puzzle part (from openscad library). Currently it is a work in progress as I only have printed the bout but it seeems that it will be OK (appart from my piezo plug which is too long to fit the slot)

For both the neck and the bout, there is the openscad file and the plate stl. Be sure to have the puzzle library (see remix from).
For the bout I had to fix it in order to be able to process it in openscad, so I added it in there), no problem with the neck. The tuner I used are the super cheap pegs (http://fr.aliexpress.com/item/6pcs-set-Zinc-Alloy-Black-Sealed-Tuning-Pegs-Tuner-Machine-Head-3R-3L-Electric-Acoustic-Guitar/1923071914.html?recommendVersion=0) that seems to fit ...perhaps a little short, but I'll see ! For the pickups, I'm using a piezzo pickup for yukulele for which the plug is a bit too long ....I'll check what I'll do later ...:)

In our Toyota Hiace campervan, converted by Trakka, we have nice little fridge, that works on 12V, 220V or LPG. When we bought it, the knob for gas was already missing. It still works, but adjusting was a pain...

Castle MakerBot is my Entry into the BotBling competition! Hope you Like it! Bot Bling Design Challenge by Carmiac: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7784 I decided to do a Castle theme. Included in Castle MakerBot are four turrets, several coat of arms, medieval wall torches, stained glass rose window, and runic keypad for the Gen4 interface. I also couldn't resist putting a dragon in there, but that is Tbuser's design. Most of this was designed in OpenScad. Originally it was designed in Sketchup, but then I learned OpenScad and started over and redesigned everything. The only thing that remains in Sketchup is the stained glass window, but I will work on moving that to OpenScad as well. If you wish to poke around in any of the OpenScad files, I highly recommend you check out the Coat of Arms. It is parametric and you have a choice of 7 different logos to be placed in 3 different positions. I have uploaded some renditions here. The Torches are made from LED Tealights! They flicker kind of like real fire. These torches were difficult to photograph in low light, but I did the best I could. The castle turrets snap right on to the rod end caps on a thing-o-matic. The stained glass rose window has some pieces printed in blue PLA, natural PLA, red ABS and black ABS. I have intentions to add a few more things to this, if I have the time. There is just so much more I want to do. Hope ya like it! Update... added this video of me showing the various parts of the castle. Focus is a little off on some of the close ups and the stills on the left probably do the project more justice. I recommend turning down the volume too, the only noises are me being clumsy and banging into things. I guess I should have talked through some of it, but it is getting late and it probably would have made the video worse than it is! ;P http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xot8MsyZZ0s

Turret: This is simple, just print. It should snap right on to the rod caps on top of any Thing-O-Matic. Coat of Arms: I have included an OpenScad file, that is parametric. You have a choice between 9 different logos in three different places on the coat of arms. Also there is an extra design for the RepRap Coat of Arms v2. The options for Logo placement are: Logo1(top left), Logo2(bottom right), Logo3 (Top Right, this one is different, in that the logo will not be a difference but extruded). Logo Options can be placed in any position and are listed here: MakerBot - MakerBot M Logo!
Thing-O-Matic - My rendition of a Thing-O-Matic printer!
Cupcake - My rendition of a cupcake! (the dessert)
Unicorn - The Unicorn Logo!
RepRap - The words RepRap in their logo's font! (Tahoma)
RepRapDrop - The RepRap drop logo!
OSHW - The OpenSource Hardware Logo! Make sure you download the OSHW-logo.dxf, Unicorn-Logo.dxf and reprap.stl to use the corresponding logos. There is also an option to disable swords by adding Swords="none" and the module for Design 2 for RepRap (Because the reprap words can be hard to read when printed small) is CoA_RepRap(); Torch: Print the torch, it comes in two pieces. You can attach the two pieces together with one m3 16mm socket cap bolt. Then, what I did was take apart an LED tealight (which you can get for a $1 each at many many stores). The tealights I got are kind of cool, because all the electronics that make it flicker are compacted into the LED itself. I wasn't expecting that. So, when I took my tealight apart, all that was in it was one CMOS style battery and one LED. Once you have a tealight apart, drop the battery and the LED into the Top of the Torch. Now, the larger hole on the mount part of the torch should fit snugly onto a socket head cap of any m3 bolt. And your done! Such SORCERY! Stained Glass Window: I printed the glass-frame.stl in black, glass-clear.stl in clear PLA, glass-blue.stl in Blue PLA, and glass-red.stl in fluorescent red ABS. After printing these items, snap them together, they should fit snugly without glue or cement. I really wish I would have had more transparent PLA colors available for the window. If I did, I would have designed the window to take up an entire side of the Bot. Runic-Stickers: Print on sticker paper and stick to your interface buttons. Left to right in the PDF it goes, UP, DN (down), LT (Left), RT (Right), GO, NO, HI, and LO. The Dragon Head Trophy was created by TBuser and can be gotten here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7457 The Unicorn Logo was made by LangfordW and can be gotten here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4197 The Open Source Hardware Logo was made by Clothbot and can be gotten here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7635

Took a model from the game and made it printer friendly. Working on the rest of the armor. These pieces are for a full sized adult, about 6 feet tall, maybe up to 6'4". The rest of the arm armor is nearly done but the scale is wrong and i haven't designed the peg slots yet. At this scale, these will fit on a makerbot/flashforge printer (about 8"x5.5"x6"). big_red_frog's helmet is linked here because it's beautifully done and there's no point inn me trying to undo that person's hard work. Not reinventing the wheel here- I just want to make a fully printable Halo armor set available for the public and I think I have a decent process in doing so. Suggestions on scaling, fasteners, etc are welcome as I am relatively new to this.

I would superglue 1/4" pegs (or rods cut to size) in, superglue the seams a tiny bit, and then use a wall plaster or putty to seal up any seams. Thin wooden dowels are very cheap and it's not worth 3d printing pegs that will crack and snap easily. I may design peg hole caps that could be 3D printed but those are minor at this point.
Let it all dry, sand it down, and paint over it for a great look without the pain and suffering of a true old school cosplayer. Note: flip parts 2 and parts 3 upside down on the print bed to save material.

A simple sabot shell to pair 3mm nails witch a 10mm blow tube. Built on a Sunday afternoon to fight boredom.
I had a spare 10 / 12 mm aluminum pipe and some 3,1x60mm nails laying around. You'll need a pipe with an inner diameter of 10mm and 3mm (or 3.1mm) thick nails with a length of at least 45mm. Use common sense and be safe !

Print at least 2 Shells, i recommend ABS or Nylon in bright colors to recover them more easily. They are reusable.  
Make sure they fit loosely in the pipe while mounting the nail, you may need to sand the ends and / or redrill the center hole.   
To add the stabilizer fins i cut off the nails head and gently hammered the printed fins onto the back of the nail.

description.text: I decided to revive the venerable iris box by redesigning it in OpenSCAD and making it printable with fewer parts and less assembly.  It's also somewhat larger (though now the dimensions are easily adjustable with OpenSCAD), the tracks are redesigned to give more rigidity when closed, and it now opens and closes according to righty-tighty, lefty-loosey.  The ring is also aesthetically redesigned and the base interior tapers down the wall thickness to give a little more internal volume.

Print the three parts (base, ring and leaves).  Note that unlike v2, the base is printed right-side up and the ring is upside down.  You can also test the mechanism with testbase, which takes much less time to print than the full base.  You can test the tolerance by clipping a leaf onto a ring peg to make sure it turns easily but doesn't wiggle.  Remove before beginning assembly.
While holding the ring upside down, place each leaf onto it as shown in the picture and hold them there with your fingers (don't clip them on yet).  Put this assembly onto the base, putting the ring pegs into the larger openings in the base.  Press down and apply a little left torque to the ring (some wiggling may be necessary) until the base pegs fall into the leaf tracks.  Now it should be possible to twist the ring back and forth a little, so twist it all the way right.  Next, line up the leaf keyed holes with the ring pegs and pop each keyhole onto each peg.  You can usually only get them on half way at first, then the second time around they'll go on all the way.  
These STLs made a very smooth mechanism on my TOM, but if your calibration gives you different results, then adjust the parameters in the scad file (peg clearance diameter is probably the most important).  
UPDATE:  I found the mechanism to be a little sticky when the box was half-way open, which turned out to be because I miscalculated the clearance for the geometry.  I've fixed the error (this version is much smoother), so the scad file and IrisLeaves.stl are new.

comments.text: Like many, i found the weakness of this design to be the ring pegs. to fix this, after printing the ring, carefully break off the pegs. you will see there is a small hole through the centre of the peg and on the ring where the pegs broke off. cut some small pieces of paperclip, you will have to work out the length. the idea is to CA glue the paperclip pieces into the peg through the hole with a small bit poking out from the peg, about 1-2mm. then put a drop of CA on the stump where the peg broke off, line up the paperclip sticking out of the peg to the small hole in the stump and push it in. this will CA glue the peg back onto the ring with the added support of the piece of paperclip through the centre of the peg and into the ring. this works well.

comments.text: You'll want to remove the lines that create the pins from the code entirely. To figure out what a line does, put a # in front of it and compile with F5. Then it'll highlight that object in red. Try commenting lines out and seeing what happens. Eventually you'll get the hang of it. If F5 is looking spastic, put a render() command in front of the top-level object. Takes a little longer, but looks much better.

comments.text: Yeah, this is a tricky one.  Even if your SF profile is perfect, a 3mm peg and a 3mm hole won't be the same size because of how ABS shrinks.  This model should be a bit better because the holes are really slots, and so don't shrink the same way.  The worst part is that the leaf thickness will always be an integer number of layer thicknesses, so every different profile will have a different tightness.  I found reducing the leaf thickness by 0.5mm helped a lot the last time I changed calibration.

comments.text: Awesome, the points are yours.  A trick with this design is that because of the angles on the pegs, the thickness of the leaves affects the tightness of the joints.  That means for a different layer thickness in SF, you'll get a slightly different leaf thickness, so you'll have to adjust the clearance accordingly.  I'd recommend increasing dc in the scad file by maybe 0.2mm or so and rebuilding the base (this is why testbase can be nice).

title: Weather in One Hour - Flip display

description.text: This machine was designed by HULK&DANSKE for the course 41030 Design of Mechatronics at DTU, dept. of Mechanical Engineering. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O_BMa3rivYo

For building instructions, please refer to our blog at
https://hulkogdanske.wordpress.com/

author: hulkogdanske

description.text:
As a part of our course, design of mechatronics, we had to create a weather station with a split-flap display. The plates are supposed to be able to fit tight together without using glue, unfortunately this is not the case.
To run an Arduino (we used the Arduino Uno) is needed along with two phototransistors (e.g. GP1S51VJ000F), two stepper motors (e.g. 28BYJ-48) and an wifi-module (e.g. ESP8266).
The Calibration.ino should be run to generate an array of index for each flap (one for temperature and one for weather) and these arrays should be copied into Vejrstation.ino (overwriting iconSteps and tempSteps) and the latter should be run on the Arduino.
A Transformers-themed, arduino controlled, split-flap weather station made for our Mechatronics course at DTU. Click here to see it in action. For more info, check out our blog.

For this project you will need:
  • Arduino uno
  • Stepper motor x 2
  • Wifi-module (ESP8266) - ATTENTION: ONLY USE 3.3 V FOR THIS COMPONENT
  • Various resistors and wires (Please check out our arduino code and each components data sheet, to see how to hook up the parts correctly)
  • Photo resistor x 2 (used for calibrating the position of the flaps) - careful these are very sensitive to short-circuits!
  • 3mm acrylic sheets x3
  • Hooks for hanging the weather station on a wall (optional)
  • Paper/cardboard sheets for the split flaps (other materials can be used as well, but keep in mind the weight will add up!)
    • We used double-sided tape to secure the motor, arduino, breadboards and photo resistors to the acrylic-housing. A different engraving can be made on the front side. To do this, simply draw the engraving in any illustration software, save as a pdf, set up the laser cutter for engraving on the selected color and go! The arduino receives data from an api on wunderground.com. We've used an hourly forecast API from Copenhagen Denmark. For other locations you need to change this location. For more information on this, visist Wunderground. Also check the code to see how to connect the components to the other pins. For more questions, please ask below. /Autobotsunite

description.text: This is a curved Lego train track with a larger radius than common Lego curved tracks. The geometry allows to have two tracks close together in parallel. However two trains with longer cars will have a problem to cross, because cars overlap more than 1 Lego unit when passing a curve. It works well with short cars.

author: MsTaylorCHS

description.text:
This is a weatherstation built with use of arduino, 3d printing and laser cutting. The weatherstation receives data from wunderground.com and displays it on a split-flap display. This thing was designed and built as an exercise in the 41030 Mechatronics Engineering Design course at the Technical University of Denmark in the spring semester of 2015. Group 4
antiheltene.wordpress.com
Parts list:

1x Arduino Uno
1x breadboard
1x ESP8266 module wifi module
1x 3.3V power supply
2x stepper motors
2x GP1A51HRJ00F photointerrupter
4x 5x11x4 mm Ballbearings
Several M3 bolts and nuts
Several Jumper cables
A usb or 12v power supply
Laser cut parts:

Display drum
Display flaps
Gears
Case 3D-printed:

Bearing holder
Wall Mount

I took the file for a 2 wheeled gear and bumped it up to 3! The best way to print this is at 100%. I separated the whole thing into 2 files because it wouldn't fit 100% on my Afinia. I did get some success scaling the full model down to fit the plate but it didn't turn as smoothly.
用於收納平板，便於充電使用

title: Small Sun Screen (Stevenson Screen) for 1-wire temperature sensors

description.text:
I was looking for a relatively small sun screen for my outdoor temperature sensors but did not find anyone that I liked. I primarily use 1-wire (DS18B20) sensors but any small sensor that will fit would work.  
After testing multiple ideas I ended up designing one that could be printed in fewer separate parts than others. The main screen is printed as one object and the mount as another one.  
I will complement the design with more mounting options later.   
Note: I have designed a larger version that i'm going to compare to the smaller one. There might be too much heat-buildup in the smaller version.

I would recommend printing the screen with 100% fill and the mount with less (like 20-50%). White color filament is needed to get as little heat-up from the sun as possible.  
The sensor could either be glued or striped into position with a cable tie.  
The efficiency of the screen has not yet been verified, if you have done any analysis, please keep me posted!

title: Leave on tool holder attachment for 2x v4

description.text:
V4 increased the width of the arms to prevent cracking when inserting the gauge. Also uploaded Inventor Part file for community modifications. Added an STL with multiple mounting points.   
Improved the design to maximize stability and provide a better platform for the dial gauge.  Added connections on the side for attaching tools giving maximum flexibility.   
The one piece clips onto the heat sinks of the 2x and provides a platform for other tools to be attached to. It's designed specifically to be left on the printer and it doesn't interfere with normal printing or leveling.   
Any attachments just need a notch so they can slide on and off the front end. I've included one attachment which is a holder for a dial gauge for leveling. I would encourage anyone to come up with additional useful attachments.

comments.author: Atbash

description.text:
Just making some props for our lovely eggplant Domo!
Made with 3mm filament, fits to the hand! 3Dプリントロリポップ
Print it and then fit with some 3D print filament of 3mm

These are some parts that can be printed to adapt a Craftbot for a E3d hotend. The design has gone through many iterations to get to this point I have not yet extensively tested the design but so far it is showing promise. This is why I have marked it as a work in progress. The three printed parts are: A spacer/bracket which holds the hotend in place and moves its position away from the carriage. A filament guide (roughly based on Scott Booker's flexible filament guide). This allows the use of flexible filament but its main purpose it to hold the PTFE tube that runs into the heatsink. This version has a hole for the tube up so far and then is just big enough for the filament the rest of the way. A Z-axis offset block which slides in place to activate the Z-axis end stop earlier (the hotend is longer). Please note that the filament guide design is loosely based on Scotbee's design found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:717962

The mod requires three printed parts, an E3d v6 hotend, 6 x m3x15 bolts and two M3 Nylon nuts. Like all good Engineers that dismantle things and put them back together again, there are spares left over (a couple of bits no longer needed. Print the parts in ABS with a lot of infill. You should not need to drill any parts out or file any parts down. When installing, I used the stock heater cartridge but swapped out the thermistor for the E3d one as the hole in the heater block is too small for the stock one. I would advise drilling out the heater block a small amount and using the stock thermistor as there is currently no way of changing the firmware for the new thermistor. The lever that moves the filament drive bearing will no longer work after this mod (I have not needed it anyway) but it will need to be put back in to position floating to add tension. The easiest way to assemble it is as follows: After dismantling the extruder:
Put the Nylon Nuts into the spaces provided in the hotend attachment.
Clip the E3d hotend into the hotend attachment, with the ptfe tube already in place.
Match the hotend attachment up to the L bracket with the ptfe tube poking through and push down the filament guide into place. (The ptfe tube will need to be cut to length, I calculated it to need to be 44mm long but it is worth confirming this for yourself).
Bolt it all to the motor, bottom left bolt first (through the filament guide) and then bottom right).
Re-install the drive gear.
Re-install the top part (leaving the bolts not completely torqued up)
Put the lever in place and re-install the spring.
Take the front fan off of the fan assembly (dangling) and re-install the fan assembly while holding the hotend attachment in place. The bolts should go through the Nylon nuts (already installed) but they will not raise it, they will just hold the front in place stopping any canter-lever motion on the hotend.
Re-install the front fan.
Install the Z axis stop tab Please use E3d's installation instructions along with this. Hopefully it is an easy enough mod to work out how to put it together from these points but if anyone has any questions, feel free to ask. Please note that these instructions and files are offered in good faith and while they worked on our Craftbot, we cannot guarantee that they will work on yours and accept no liability whatsoever for any damages caused by following these steps.

comments.text: hi! I'm interested in that camera, how is it? in terms of picture quality and range,distance?
comments.author: mirkolone

comments.text:
I am very impressed with it. I now have two 110deg. and two 148deg.
Quality is not HD. But it is as good as my Sony CCD 700. Much better low light that my Mobius or Gopro. Transitions fast between light and dark.
Range I have gotten up to ~100m in the tree line. Open space, I have gotten out to ~300m still with good clarity(only because I'm trying to stay within public property). Note I am using Skyzone goggles that have diversity receivers and no directional antennas at this point.
Biggest improvement I found was these antennas for the transmitter.
http://www.banggood.com/Boscam-5_8Ghz2_4Ghz-Broadband-Mushroom-Antenna-For-FPV-TxRx-p-965756.html
You will need SMA male for the transmitter

description.text:
I decided to go with a Brain flight controller setup on my T4. I redesigned the top plate to have some captured nuts that can be screwed into from the top once the top plate is installed. I added a separate isolated mounting plate for the camera. I was having major stability issues with too much mass on the flight controller isolated plate. I will have to post the flight controller plate later once I recreate it(my file got corrupted). I use 100g iso balls between the plate and 3m X 5 screws and lock nuts to attach from the T4 top plate to the component plate Update 6/3/15
Finally got a chance to recreate the isolated flight controller plate. 31 x 31mm spacing for the flight controller.

description.text: first useful model i've built so far
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gbcOUgRf4er
This is a fan duct to keep your E3D v5 hotend "cold". I did not found any design that I've liked, than I decided to make one myself.
Just print it, I recommend it to be printed standing up, not with the fan side down. This will make it not break when you put in the hotend.

comments.text: Were the nut holes designed for square or hexagon nuts? I could fit hex nuts at the bottom (inserted from inside) but top holes were too small for them (I used nuts and bolts included with stock fan support by Sunhokey). Also, I printed in ABS standing up and could not achieve proper bridging on the top lip so it was incomplete. I tried fitting it nonetheless and I should note that the fit was not super tight - this model could benefit from longer side supports and probably one more inner lip to fit between radiator fins.

comments.text: The nuts holes were designed for hexagonal nuts. I'm really sorry if it didn't worked out perfectly for you. I'm sure that it can be improved a lot, thanks for your thoughts!

author: hetarek

title: Decap tray for RCS reloading press

description.text: Replacement for the inverted "Y" tray on RCBS Rock Chucker Supreme reloading press. (Updated5/18 to improve support removal.) Fits behind the ram, retained by a lug in the frame slot and slotted ring around ram. Remove shellholder before installing or removing the tray. Select preferred version for a hose that goes on either the left side or right side of the frame, then down to a small bottle or plastic jug to hold the spent primers and black debris. Default version prints upright from STL files with support and 4mm brim in ABS or PLA. [email protected] for questions or support.

Due to the nozzle bore, you will need to use support, but it can be  4mm or 5mm spacing.   It simply rams out of the tube with a large hex key. Use handheld 3/8" twist drill to smooth the bore.  Hose is 4 or 5 feet of 1/2" or 13mm ID clear vinyl flex tubing available from local hardware store.  
Bed temperature may need to be 10C above normal, to reduce warping of ABS.  Source files include a"wHS" option "with Heat Shield" to keep the piece flat on the build tray for ABS, especially if your print table is small or slightly cold.  shield pieces trim off after the print cools.  
Print anywhere in the 0.25 to 0.35 mm layer height, ABS or PLA, with 0.3 rectilinear or 0.2 honeycomb fill, at least 3 perimeters and 4 top and bottom layers.  
A spent 22 cal case is perfect for the hole in the right leg, to pin it to the press frame, but is not usually necessary.   Universal decap dies let the metal pieces drop gently and will sometimes clog 3 or 4 primers, then drop as a group.  You can see each primer drop down the clear plastic tube.

comments.text:
Have posted a better version for RCBS Supreme IV press kits.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148190
With a spacer behind the plastic (M4 bolt), you do not need the ring to hold it in place.
comments.author: lcecil

comments.text: This is a fantastic upgrade for the otherwise awesome RCBS RockChucker single stage press!  I, like many, get frustrated by the stock decap tray which lets primers escape and fall on the floor.  Well done & much appreciated!  After printing this, my stock decap tray is off to the dust bin.

title: Kodak 616 to 120 film adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This adapter allows you to fit standard 120-size film into an older Kodak six-16 camera (popular in the 1930s). The Brownie six-16 was a popular model. Based on an instructional PDF by this guy over here: http://home.comcast.net/~peter.lerro/site/

If you 3d print this, then stick one on each end of your 120 film spool, the film will fit in your camera! You will still need to modify the film gate and mask the viewfinder to get good results, but at least this lets you wind film through it. A good walkthrough can be found in the following PDF: http://home.comcast.net/~peter.lerro/616panoramicconversion-RevB.pdf

author: raindrift

description.text:
I made this spacer because the sunroof on my car would get hung-up when trying to close on the little feet at the bottom of the fairing mount. The spacer fits perfectly into the open space on the underside of each fairing mount. The slope on the spacer causes the sunroof to push the fairing up and out of the way so it can close. I have a Jetta Sportwagen with the panoramic sunroof. Because the sunroof size extends further forward then most cars the fairing ends up being positioned ontop of the sunroof when mounted. This spacer allows for you to have the fairing on the car and still close the sunroof without any binding. Directions:
1.) Print out 4 of these.
2.) If in direct sunlight coat with a UV resistant paint
3.) Enjoy the fresh air :)

description.text: Oye! Oye! Brenda the articulated battle tardigrade has been released into the wilds of 3D printing! Join the Horde to be among the first humanoids to learn about the next epic project from Zheng Labs! We now return you to your regular model description.

This iteration of the popular tabletop wargame incorporates feedback and design ideas from the 3D printing community to make the game more exciting than ever! The new catapults are a vast improvement on their predecessors; they're easier to assemble, print more quickly, and are uncannily accurate. Extensive playtesting leads us to recommend 14mm marbles and size 32 rubber bands for the game. Improved weapons require improved defenses, so the new bloxen now interlock on multiple sides for a tighter fit. Rules for Seej are at www.s33j.net. Have at thee! Eye protection strongly recommended.

description.text:
A Bluetooth controlled eye, mounted on over-sized glasses.
Move your eye using a smartphone and scare your friends on Halloween...
  • No screws or nuts!
  • No support needed!
  • Printed on Printrbot Simple 10cm^3 (~4'') using PLA. Layer height = 0.35mm
    • https://youtu.be/RC3_Y2uLQr4

For this project you'll need:
  • 22mm doll's eye
  • 9gr 5v servo motor (used in RC planes/cars)
  • any Arduino
  • soldering iron or a Breadboard
  • some connector wires
  • few drops of hot-glue
  • smartphone with a Bluetooth app
    • Estimated total print time: 3 hours
  • Print the ear parts and the connector in one color and the rest in another.
  • Although some joints fit tightly, I used hot glue to slightly melt the PLA and make it stick.
    • Part 1- Assembly - http://youtu.be/aX-RYNmWuUc
    Part 2 - Electronics - https://youtu.be/SqqAAPuXaSc
    Code download: http://makestuffordie.blogspot.co.il/2015/12/bionic-hipster-glasses-code-behind.html
